instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - green light, no liquid damage, sudden shutdown.
threads.message:
Hello guys,

I got a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> macbook that has no signs of liquid damage. The customer brought it because it was shutting down out of nowhere. What should I measure first?

Thank you

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - green light, no liquid damage, sudden shutdown.
threads.message:
First of all check 3V42 and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Do you get amber light on Magsafe connector?
Next check <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS.
ALso check for any pulse on big coils.


BTW, use Magsafe 2 charger, not 1 --> 2 adapter.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - green light, no liquid damage, sudden shutdown.
threads.message:
Hello,

amber light on Magsafe connector OK. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.51V, pp3v42 3.39V. 

I don't know what the /SUS part in <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS is, can you explain?

Also, I have no oscilloscope to check for pulses... is there any other way?

Thank you

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - green light, no liquid damage, sudden shutdown.
threads.message:
Check for pulses means to check if you get any voltage pulse; no need an o-scope.
Of course, o-scope is better, but not really needed to see if a voltage tries to appear.

<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS means <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>; usually we try to write the essential...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - green light, no liquid damage, sudden shutdown.
threads.message:
Thank you for clearing that up. Big coil L7520 seems to give a tiny voltage 0.02v at initial contact, but then drops to zero. Big coil L7130 is 12.50V. 

Measured <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is 3.32v and _SUS is 0V 


Kind reminder, the Macbook is not steady. Sometimes it will not boot at all; other times it boots but shuts down after some seconds and other times it boots into the operating system and can work for several minutes.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - green light, no liquid damage, sudden shutdown.
threads.message:
Try if works on SMC bypass mode.
Is that dropped machine?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - green light, no liquid damage, sudden shutdown.
threads.message: Client says it has not been dropped but who knows, right? Unfortunately, even in SMC bypass mode it does the sudden shutdown...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - green light, no liquid damage, sudden shutdown.
threads.message:
Try only MLB on the desk; RIO board disconnected.
Just use an USB mouse for test, or USB OSX with Link LED.
